dc:description: LIFR is located on chromosome 5 at 5p13.1 and encodes leukemia inhibitory factor receptor protein. LIFR was first reported in relation to autosomal recessive Stüve-Wiedemann syndrome in 2004 (Dagoneau et al., PMID 14740318). At least 28 unique variants (nonsense, frameshift, splicing, missense, gross deletions) have been reported in affected individuals, 22 of which are predicted to cause a loss of function of the protein, suggesting biallelic loss of function is the mechanism of disease for this gene. Variants in this gene have been reported in at least 22 probands in four publications (Dagoneau et al., 2004, PMID 14740318; Jung et al., 2010, PMID 20447141; Yeşil et al., 2014, PMID 24988918; Maddirevula et al., 2018, PMID 29620724). Additional genetic evidence is available in the literature; however, the maximum score for genetic evidence (12 pts) was reached. Further evidence supporting this gene-disease relationship includes functional alteration experiments and a LIFR-deficient mouse model, which recapitulates several features of the disease phenotype, including feeding difficulties, skeletal abnormalities, decreased bone volume and nervous system dysfunction (Dagoneau et al., 2004 PMID 14740318; Bellais et al., 2010 PMID 19603067; Ware et al., 1995 PMID 7789261). In summary, LIFR is definitively associated with autosomal recessive Stüve-Wiedemann syndrome. This has been repeatedly demonstrated in both the research and clinical diagnostic settings, and has been upheld over time. This classification was approved by the ClinGen Syndromic Disorders Gene Curation Expert Panel on the meeting date 2Sept2020 (SOP Version 7).

evidence.dc:description: LIFR -/- mice demonstrated feeding difficulties, skeletal abnormalities, decreased bone volume and increased osteoclast numbers, similar to the human SWS phenotype. Fewer than expected LIFR -/- pups were born, and LIFR -/- pups died before, during or shortly after birth, while individuals with SWS often survive longer but often succumb in the neonatal period or infancy. Although some LIFR -/- pups were smaller in size, this was not a defining feature, whereas SWS individuals are characterized by short stature and small extremities. LIF and OSM significantly stimulated MAP kinase activation in LIFR +/+ and +/- cultured cells but not in LIFR -/- cells. LIFR +/+ and +/− sensory neurons survived in the presence of cytokines that are known to use LIFR to mediate signal transduction events (LIF, CNTF, or OSM), whereas sensory neurons from the LIFR−/− littermates did not survive in the presence of these cytokines. These findings are consistent with impaired signaling of LIFR. LIFR -/- fetuses also displayed disrupted placental architecture, fewer spinal and brainstem astrocytes, and elevated glycogen in liver.
evidence.rdfs:label: Targeted disruption of LIFR in mouse

evidence.dc:description: Gene alteration not reported. No points, due to the possibility of this being the same model as reported in Ware et al., 1995, PMID 7789261

LIF, CNTF, and CT-1 are synthesized in embryonic adrenal gland and spinal cord and PSNs express LIFRβ.PSNs in the spinal cord were reduced and PSNs projecting the the adrenal medulla were more severely affected. Levels of adrenaline and adrenaline-synthesizing cells were reduced. Loss of motor neurons and nerve disfunction is consistent with the SWS phenotype.
evidence.rdfs:label: Loss of LIFR in PSN and adrenal medulla

evidence.dc:description: Same model as Ware et al., 1995, PMID 7789261

"Analysis of Lifr-/- mice suggests that CNTF/LIF/gp130 signaling maintains a subpopulation of GSH2+ VZ precursors, which are necessary for normal growth of the early ventral forebrain and for maintaining a gradient of VZ precursor differentiation in the lateral ganglionic eminence, as defined by GSH2, MASH1 and DLX2 expression." Nervous system disfunction is a phenotype of SWS.
evidence.rdfs:label: CNTF/LIF/gp130 receptor complex signaling

evidence.dc:description: Same model as Ware et al., 1995, PMID 7789261

"LIFRβ signaling is not required for the specification of motor neuron, astrocyte and oligodendrocyte, in a first phase of facial nucleus development. However, in a second step, fbm neurons’ identity is modified and the number of generated astrocytes and oligodendrocytes is reduced in absence of LIFRβ signaling...signaling via LIFRβ exerts important influences upon motor neuron identity determination and glial differentiation during mouse facial nucleus development." LIFRβ-/- embryos showed modification in the combination of genes expressed in fbm neurons and reduced numbers of astrocytes and oligodendrocytes in the facial nucleus. Loss of motor neurons and nerve disfunction is consistent with the SWS phenotype.
evidence.rdfs:label: The role of LIFR in the mouse facial nucleus

evidence.dc:description: Similar to another functional alteration study

"RT-PCR analysis of fibroblast RNA transcripts detected either no amplification product (patient 4) or a weak signal (patients 7 and 10)", compared to controls. "Binding experiments on patient and control fibroblasts through use of iodinated LIF revealed that fibroblasts from patients 1, 4, 7, and 10 failed to express high-affinity LIF receptors, whereas control fibroblasts bound LIF with an apparent Kd of 0.9 nM and a maximum capacity of 1,500 sites/cell...The activation of STAT3 in response to LIF was tested in patient and control fibroblasts. Western blot analysis of fibroblast lysates from patients 1, 4, and 7 with an
antiphospho STAT3 antibody showed that STAT3 failed to be phosphorylated in response to LIF (5-min stimulation), whereas LIF normally triggered STAT3 phosphorylation in control cells. Similar results were obtained after 30 min. Consistently, immunofluorescence
analysis showed that incubation with LIF (15 min) triggered nuclear localization of STAT3 in control fibroblasts, whereas fibroblasts from patient 10 exhibited an exclusive cytoplasmic staining."
evidence.rdfs:label: RT-PCR and Binding Analysis in LIFR-null Fibroblasts

evidence.dc:description: Similar to another functional alteration study

Western-blot analysis using anti-phospho-STAT3 and anti-actin antibodies showed STAT3 failed to be phosphorylated in response to LIF in cultured SWS patient fibroblasts, homozygous for nonsense mutations. Reverse transcriptase PCR analysis of LIFR transcripts demonstrated a weak signal in the three patients compared with control fibroblasts.
evidence.rdfs:label: In vitro readthrough of PTC's by gentamycin in SWS

evidence.dc:description: Consanguineous

evidence.rdfs:label: Family 1
evidence.detectionMethod:
11 SWS families (10 consanguineous and 1 nonconsanguineous) were used in homozygosity-mapping analysis. Disease was mapped to 5p13.1 at locus D5S418.”  

A series of 42 intronic primers was designed to amplify the 20 coding exons of the LIFR gene. Amplification products were purified and sequenced using the fluorescent dideoxy-terminator method on an automatic sequencer, ABI 3100."
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: “All families fulfilled the diagnostic criteria for SWS, namely bowing of the long bones with flared metaphyses, feeding difficulties, respiratory distress, and hyperthermic episodes.”

evidence.dc:description:
Paper states, "Blood samples were obtained with the written consent of the patients and unaffected relatives" but does not explicitly state if parental testing was performed to confirm phase. 

No evidence of gene impact presented in the paper for missense variant  c.835T>C(S279P)

evidence.rdfs:label: Family 11
evidence.detectionMethod:
11 SWS families (10 consanguineous and 1 nonconsanguineous) were used in homozygosity-mapping analysis. Disease was mapped to 5p13.1 at locus D5S418.”  

“A series of 42 intronic primers was designed to amplify the 20 coding exons of the LIFR gene. Amplification products were purified and sequenced using the fluorescent dideoxy-terminator method on an automatic sequencer, ABI 3100."
evidence.phenotypeFreeText:
“All families fulfilled the diagnostic criteria for SWS, namely bowing of the long bones with flared metaphyses, feeding difficulties, respiratory distress, and hyperthermic episodes.” 

“...presented with a severe bowing of the long bones, with prominent joints, severe spinal deformity, and normal mental development. Neurological symptoms included temperature instability, absent corneal and patellar reflexes, and smooth tongue. Radiological changes included undertubulation of diaphyses and rarefaction and striation of metaphyses.”

evidence.dc:description: Same genotype as another scored case

evidence.phenotypeFreeText: Oxygen dependency due to recurrent respiratory infections and respiratory failure

forms of gross facial and skeletal dysmorphism.
